**Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Lord Lao**

**Scripture Title:** *Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Lord Lao* (One Scroll)

**Source Text:** *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongshen* Section, Registers and Genealogies Category.

---

The Most High Lord Lao is the ancestral origin of the Dao, embodying spontaneity. He existed before the Three Pure Ones, prior to the Primordial Emperor, and reigned as the Jade Emperor, dwelling in the Jade Clarity Golden Palace.

Within the netherworld’s dark depths, the Hollow Void arose; from the Hollow Void emerged the Great Nothingness; the Great Nothingness transformed to generate the Three Blacks of Primordial Mystery. After countless eons of transformation, the Three Blacks gave birth to the Mysterious Jade Maiden, the Lady of Primordial Origin, whose divine countenance and wondrous form were of jade-like subtlety.

At that time, the Three Blacks remained undifferentiated in primordial chaos. The Jade Maiden ascended to the Great Clarity Golden Palace, while Lord Lao wandered beyond the Era of Grand Simplicity, abiding at the extremity of the Supreme Ultimate. There, he divided the Two Modes and thus engendered the Three Powers. Once the Three Powers were complete, the myriad existences came into being.

Lord Lao then responded to the needs of the age, assuming titles in turn: the Nameless Lord of Governance, the Lofty and Supreme Lord of the Void, the Most High Lord, the Teacher of the Upper Three Sovereigns, the Teacher of the Middle Three Sovereigns, the Teacher of the Lower Three Sovereigns, and the Teacher of the Five Emperors. From the dawn of creation until the reign of Emperor Shun, he served as the unbroken preceptor of the world for two million, seven hundred fifty-eight thousand, four hundred years and more.

Lord Lao commanded the divine messenger Xuan Yi of Mount Wanwei to bestow upon Yu the Jade Writ. Yu unsealed the golden tablets and silver-bound registers, obtaining the means to regulate the waters. Thereafter, Lord Lao ascended to the Jade Clarity Golden Palace. After the flood’s governance, the text was concealed within the Grotto of the Forest Chamber.

Following Shun’s reign, virtue and the Dao declined below, and after a thousand-year cycle of the world’s destiny, a sage was destined to appear. At that time, Lord Lao emerged as the world’s teacher, manifesting his birth by entrusting himself to the Jade Lady’s jade body within her jeweled palace. The Jade Lady, reposing in the Great Clarity Golden Palace, dreamed of a solar essence vast as a shooting star entering her mouth. She swallowed it, awoke pregnant, and descended to the world for eighty-one years.

On the fifteenth day of the second month, the *gengchen* year of the third reign of King Wuding of Yin (13th century BCE), the Jade Lady, accompanied by thirty-six jade lads and thirty-six jade maidens, descended to the land of Youbo. There, a palace of natural mist and cloud arose, with a thousand gates and ten thousand portals, guarded by celestial soldiers and divine warriors.

At that moment, the Jade Lady gave birth to Lord Lao from beneath her left armpit. Nine dragons proffered waters to bathe the sacred body, and where the dragons emerged, nine wells formed. The solar lad scattered radiance, and the lunar consort bore blossoms.

The sagely lord could speak immediately upon birth. Retreating nine steps, he caused nine-colored lotuses to bloom with each stride. Pointing to a plum tree, he declared, “This shall be my surname.” Then he proclaimed, “Within the Three Realms, I alone am their ancestral origin.”

Clad in the spontaneous raiment of heaven, he suddenly grew to nine feet in height. His jade countenance and golden body bore cinnabar lips and jade teeth; his ears rose above his crown. His visage combined the solar angle and lunar mystery, possessing ten thousand perfect features beyond enumeration.

Marveling at his appearance, all exclaimed, “The sage is profound! Born before heaven and earth, he does not age; abiding after heaven and earth, he does not grow young. Though born with white hair, he is called *Laozi* (Old Master).”

At the time of his descent and birth, the divine immortals and the Supreme Lord of the Void paid homage in midair, reciting his ten titles: (1) Jade Emperor, (2) Primordial Sage, (3) Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, (4) Unsurpassed Venerable, (5) Lord of the Dao, (6) Nameless Lord, (7) Lofty and Supreme Lord of the Void, (8) Most High Lord, (9) Lord Lao, and (10) Teacher of Emperors.

Having spoken, they bowed their heads in reverence to Lord Lao and took their leave. The host of celestial immortals then arrayed their heavenly processions, clouds veiling the sky, to welcome the Sacred Mother’s return to the Heaven of Great Clarity.

On the day of Lord Lao’s descent and birth, whenever the sun rose, incense was burned and flowers scattered. As the Sacred Mother ascended to heaven, celestial incense and the resonant tones of the Hollow Void filled the world. Those who studied immortality transmitted these sounds among themselves, creating the *Step of the Void* melody, which is none other than the voice of heaven.

When the Sacred Mother ascended, she left behind one sandal. The immortals interred it as a tomb, which was thereafter called the *Tomb of the Sacred Mother’s Ascension*.

Lord Lao also cultivated the Dao in Bo, where a well for refining the elixir remains. When King Xin of Yin grew tyrannical, the Supreme Emperor sought a sage to aid the realm. Lord Lao, seated in the Golden Palace, received the Emperor’s homage. The Emperor said, “King Xin is cruel and deluded; the people have no master. Only the Earl of the West, Ji Chang, possesses the Dao. I humbly beseech the Most High to protect him with compassion.”

Lord Lao assented to the Emperor’s request and descended to the southern slope of Mount Qi, dwelling as a recluse. The Earl of the West, Ji, appointed him as the Archivist of the Royal Repository. He transmitted the Dao of emperors and kings, aiding Lü Shang and King Wu of Zhou in overthrowing the Shang.

In the first year of King Zhao’s reign, he was appointed as the Historian Beneath the Pillars. In the twenty-fifth year of King Zhao’s reign (*guichou*, 974 BCE), he passed through the Hangu Pass, intending to journey to the Western Rong lands.

Earlier, Yin Xi, a grandee of King Kang skilled in astrology, had retired to serve as the Pass Prefect. He built a thatched tower to observe the stars and await auspicious omens. Suddenly, he saw a purple qi rising in the east, serpentine as a dragon, moving westward. He urgently instructed the pass officers, “A sage is about to pass. If you see an ancient-looking figure traveling discreetly in a carriage drawn by a black ox, do not let him slip by.”

The officers replied, “Understood.” They then swept the roads and burned incense to await his arrival.

Then, as foretold, the officers detained him for inquiry. Yin Xi beheld him and prostrated himself, kowtowing, saying, “Your servant earlier divined the omen of the purple qi. Now, beholding the Dao Lord’s countenance and form, could this not be the great divine personage of highest antiquity?”

The Old Lord replied, “You are able to know me; I am able to know you.”

Xi said, “I venture to ask the Dao Lord’s name.”

The Old Lord said, “My name is vast and boundless, spanning kalpas from one to the next, not to be fully recounted. Now, my surname is Li, my given name Er, my courtesy name Boyang, and my sobriquet Lao Dan.”

Xi, with utmost sincerity, lodged him in a guesthouse, prostrated himself, and kowtowed, humbly entreating instruction. The Old Lord, wishing to transmit the Dao, tested Xi’s resolve. Suddenly, he soared into the air, transforming into a golden body eighteen feet tall. Xi, astonished and reverent, prostrated himself and kowtowed, saying, “The Dao Lord is supremely sagely and divine, his transformations unfathomable. Your servant’s blood and saliva are foul and impure; to be graced with an audience of your celestial presence fills me with awe and joy. I humbly entreat your instruction.”

The Old Lord said, “Attend carefully to my command: I bestow upon you the *Daodejing*. Master it, and you shall ascend to heaven, becoming a master of immortals.”

Xi replied, “Though your servant has long purified his heart, I have been mired in the floating world. Yet by karmic fortune, I have received this sacred grace.” He bowed twice, kowtowed, and received the scripture, then said, “I reverently embrace this profound decree, seeking only to cultivate and perfect it to the end of my days, never daring to neglect or lose it. By upholding this covenant, reciting in purity, I shall retire from office and attain perfection.”

Later, he visited the Old Lord, who appointed Xi as the Celestial Lord of the Twenty-Eight Heavens, the Supreme Perfected One. Initially, the Old Lord had revealed his golden body to Xi, but afterward, he resumed his true form of the Nine Heavens. Taking leave of Xi, he journeyed west to the eighty-one lands beyond the Flowing Sands. Arriving in India, he propagated the arts of the floating pagoda to transform the Hu people, and in that land, all called him the Venerable Master of Antiquity.

In the forty-fourth year (*renshen*, 953 BCE), on the eighth day of the second month, Śākyamuni received the Dao from him in Yucheng. With each sentence of the scripture he received, his body merged with the Great Ultimate, and the Supreme Emperor paid homage from afar. After reciting it ten thousand times, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Truly, when reciting scriptures, one must seek a place of purity and stillness, unifying heart and spirit, meditating upon the Primal Sage. Thus, the ninefold ancestors and sevenfold forebears shall all be reborn in heaven. The text is secretly preserved in the Golden Towers of the Three Clarities and the immortal caves of various mountains, inscribed on golden tablets and jade slips, attended by immortal youths and maidens who burn incense in vigil. When the great kalpa turns and the world nears its end, the Lords of the Grotto-Heavens shall gather the texts and return them to the Golden Towers of the Grand Clarity.

In the fifth year of King Mu’s reign (*jiashen*, 972 BCE), the Old Lord returned to the Central Kingdom and transmitted to the king the arts of immortal travel and aerial chariotry. In the twenty-eighth year of King Xuan’s reign (*xinchou*, 801 BCE), the Three Rivers trembled. The king asked the Old Lord, “What is this portent?”

The Old Lord replied, “I have heard a song in the suburbs: ‘When Venus enters Xuanyuan, the state’s ruler shall decline.’ In the reign of King You, Mount Qi collapsed. The Old Lord said, ‘In ancient times, when the Yi and Luo rivers dried, the Xia perished; when the Yellow River dried, the Shang perished. Now, Mount Qi has collapsed and the rivers have run dry—this state shall perish.’” The Old Lord bestowed upon the king the *Hidden Writ of the Three Heavens*, but the king did not revere the celestial texts. The Old Lord retrieved the writ and departed, and the king was later slain by the Quan Rong.

In the third year of King Huan’s reign (*jiazi*, 717 BCE), the Old Lord rode a white deer, accompanied by twenty-four immortals, with Guiguzi as his charioteer. He ascended Kunlun in the west and passed through Hangu Pass again. The Celestial Lord of the Twenty-Eight Heavens, the Supreme Perfected One, learned of the Old Lord’s return and descended from heaven to pay homage, following his carriage to the Palace of the Queen Mother before taking leave. The Old Lord then appointed Xi as the Celestial Lord of the Thirty-Two Heavens.

In the seventeenth year of King Xiang’s reign (*yiyou*, 635 BCE), the Old Lord returned to the Central Kingdom. The king’s scribe, whose name was later changed to Danran, revered him. Confucius traveled to Zhou and inquired of the rites from the Old Lord. The Old Lord said, “The man of whom you speak—his bones have long since decayed; only his words remain. I have heard that a good merchant conceals his wealth as if empty, and a gentleman of great virtue appears foolish. Rid yourself of your pride, anger, and excessive desires, for these bring no benefit to your person. This is why I tell you thus.”

Confucius departed and said to his disciples, “Birds—I know they can fly, and so I make snares. Beasts—I know they can run, and so I make nets. Fish—I know they can swim, and so I make lines. But as for the dragon, I cannot know how it rides the wind and clouds to ascend heaven. Today, I have seen Laozi—is he not like the dragon? I am but a mayfly in comparison.”

Confucius returned to Lu and declared Laozi a sage of all directions, one who is trusted without speaking, who transforms without governing—truly, he may be called a sage. One hundred and nineteen years after Confucius’ death, the Old Lord appeared to Duke Xian of Qin, saying, “At first, Qin and Zhou were united; after five hundred years, they separated. Ten years after their separation, a hegemon-king shall arise.” At that time, he was called the Grand Historian of Zhou.

The Old Lord was born in the time of King Wuding of Shang. Sometimes he appeared, sometimes he concealed himself, dwelling in the world for nine hundred years before ascending Mount Zizhu in the Purple Tenuity. The mountain lies within the borders of Quren County, and thus it is called the Ascension Mound of Laozi.

The Mystic Master says: I have perused all the records of the Dao, seeking their essential meaning. Yet many who delight in immortality have fabricated and compiled recklessly. When examining their historical accounts, the dates often conflict, and when tracing their wondrous traces, the beginnings and ends are scattered and incoherent, their words empty and extravagant, losing all truth. Such matters are not trivial, and I have omitted them entirely. I have instead consulted external sources and verified them against the jade tablets, recording only what is indelible through the ages. I title this the *Inner Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Old Lord*, leaving a true record to correct the floating words.

Here ends the *Inner Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Old Lord*.

chunks.original_text: 太上老君金书内序 经名：太上老君金书内序。 一卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部谱录类。 太上老君金书内序 老君为道之宗，体於自然，在乎三清之前，象帝之先，为玉皇帝，居玉清金阙。 下界幽冥之中生空洞，空洞之中生太无，太无变化生玄元始三黑。 三黑变化，经无数亿劫，化生玉容神姿玄妙玉女元君。 时三黑混沌，未有所分，元君上升太清金阙，老君遂游乎太易之先，居乎太极之端，分判两仪，遂生三才。 三才既备，化生万有。 老君乃应号治世，无名君治、高上虚皇治、太上治、上三皇师、中三皇师、下三皇师、五帝师。 从开辟至虞舜问，世为师不绝，经二百七十五万八千四百余年。 老君命宛委山之神玄夷使者，授禹玉书，禹发金简银编得治水之卫，老君上升玉清金阙。 治水后，其文藏于林屋洞。 舜后道德下衰，下界一千年运会，圣人合出。 是时老君出为世师，示其诞育，遂托於元君玉身琼府。 元君在太清金阙昼寝，梦日精大如流星，飞入口中，咽觉有娠，下界八十一年。 殷武丁三年庚辰二月十五日，元君与玉童、玉女各三十六人降於有亳之地，以有自然结烟云之官，千门万户，复有天丁力士侍卫。 是时，元君从左腋降诞老君。 是时，九龙荐水以沐圣躬，其龙出处化成九井。 是时，日童散彩，月妃捧华。 圣君寻即能言，却行九步，皆生九色莲花，乃指李树，此为我姓也。 复日：三界之内，宗余一人。 服自然天衣，忽长九尺，玉容金身，口丹齿玉，耳高於顶，日角月玄，万相端备，不可胜言也。 异其相，咸日：圣人厚，其生天地之先不老，居天地之后不少，生而发白，故号日老子。 降诞其时，诸神仙虚皇上帝朝礼空中，称十号。 一日玉皇，二曰元圣，三曰元始天尊，四日无上尊，五日道君，六曰无名君，七曰高上虚皇君，八曰太上，九曰老君，十曰帝师。 言毕，稽首礼老君而辞。 其诸天神仙驾天仗，排云蔽空，以迎圣母归太清天。 缘降诞老君之日，每至日焚香散花，圣母归天时，在世问作天香空洞之音，学仙之士因而相受为步虚之音，本即天声也。 圣母升夭时，遗下一只履，天人葬之为陵，因号圣母升天陵。 老君於亳亦以修行，有练丹井。 帝辛昏虐，上帝思有麟边。 老君於金阙正座，上帝朝拜曰：帝辛昏虐，苍生无主，惟西伯姬昌有道，伏愿太上以慈卫之。 老君允上帝之请，降於岐山之阳，为隐士，西伯姬征为守藏室史。 授帝王之道，与吕尚、周武王克商。 元年举为柱下史。 昭王二十有五年癸丑，过函谷关，将适西戎。 初，康王大夫尹喜善星历，退为关令，结草为楼，瞻星候黑。 忽见束方有紫黑，状如龙蛇而西度，喜劫关吏日：圣人将过，如有古人状，微行车驾青牛，勿放过。 吏日：诺。 遂扫路焚香待之。

chunks.original_text: 后果然，吏留之咨。 喜见，拜首稽首日：臣先占紫黑之兆，今观道君状貌，岂非上古大神人者乎。 老君曰：子能知吾，吾能知子。 喜曰：敢问道君姓名。 老君曰：吾姓名渺渺，从劫到劫，非可悉说。 吾今姓李，名耳字伯阳，外字老聘。 喜馆之精诚，拜首稽首，敢请诲言。 老君欲授道，使喜心至，忽飞行空中，为丈八黄金之身。 喜乃精异，拜首稽首日：道君大圣大神，变化不测，臣血诞腥秽，幸会天颜，臣以惶以喜，敢请诲言。 老君日：汝敬听我命，授汝《道德经》，克享升天，为仙师者师。 喜日：臣虽斋心已久，沉迩浮世，实以宿庆，获奉圣恩。 再拜稽首受经，复日：钦若玄旨，求惟进修，克以终天，罔敢失坠。 依盟斋诵，退官成真。 后诣老君，命喜为无上真人二十八天天主。 初，老君示喜黄金身，后却复九天真形，与喜别，西适流沙八十一国。 至于天竺，作浮图之术，以化胡人，其国皆号老君为有古先生。 至四十四年壬申二月八日，释氏瑜城於我受道，其经每受一句，则身参太极，上帝遥礼。 诵之万遍，白日升天。 夫诵经当须清静之处，心神精一，存想元圣，九玄七祖皆得生天。 其文秘在三清金阙及诸山仙洞，并金书玉简，仙童仙女焚香侍卫，下界至大劫交运，天地归尽，洞天之君收其文，送太清金阙。 穆王五年甲申，老君复还中国，授王泞游仙驾空之术。 宣王二十八年辛丑，三川震动，王问老君：是何祥也。 老君日：郊闻汉父歌日：太白入勖国将衰。 幽王年，岐山崩，老君日：昔伊洛竭而夏亡，河竭而商亡，岐山崩、川竭，国将亡。 老君授王《三天隐文》，王不崇天文，老君收文而去，王为犬戎所杀。 桓王三年甲子，束驾白鹿，与二十四仙人，鬼谷子为驭，西登昆仑，重过函谷。 时无上真人二十八天主知老君重过关，遂下天朝拜，随驾至王母馆而辞，老君令喜为三十二天天主。 襄王十有七年乙酉，老君还中国，王师之为太史，更名澹然敬王年，孔子适周，问礼於老君，老君日：子之所言，其人骨皆已朽矣，独其言在耳。 吾闻良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德容貌若愚，去子之骄）？ 气与淫志，是皆无益子之身，吾是以告子若是。 孔子去，谓弟子曰：乌，吾知其能飞，可以为缯。 兽，吾知其能走，可以为网。 鱼，吾知其能游，可以为纶。 至於龙，吾不能知其乘风云而上天，吾今日见老子，其犹龙耶，吾犹酝鸡焉。 孔子返鲁，称老子为万方圣人，不言而自信，不治而自化，可为圣耶。 孔子卒后一百一十九年，老君见秦献公日：始秦与周合，合五百年而离，离十年而霸王者出焉。 时谓之周太史。 老君从武丁时生，或出或隐，经九百年在世，然后登山上升紫微。 其山在整座县界，因号老子升天陵焉。 玄师曰：余曾遍览道记，求其指归，然好仙士有妄为撰集，为勘其史册，多年代不同，究其玄迹则首尾汗漫，言空尚异，反丧其真。 事既非轻，全并不录。 余当外考典据，上符玉书，言其不刊之久，题日《老子金书内序》，永贻真录，以革浮言矣。 太上老君金书内序竟
chunks.translated_text:
Then, as foretold, the officers detained him for inquiry. Yin Xi beheld him and prostrated himself, kowtowing, saying, “Your servant earlier divined the omen of the purple qi. Now, beholding the Dao Lord’s countenance and form, could this not be the great divine personage of highest antiquity?”

The Old Lord replied, “You are able to know me; I am able to know you.”

Xi said, “I venture to ask the Dao Lord’s name.”

The Old Lord said, “My name is vast and boundless, spanning kalpas from one to the next, not to be fully recounted. Now, my surname is Li, my given name Er, my courtesy name Boyang, and my sobriquet Lao Dan.”

Xi, with utmost sincerity, lodged him in a guesthouse, prostrated himself, and kowtowed, humbly entreating instruction. The Old Lord, wishing to transmit the Dao, tested Xi’s resolve. Suddenly, he soared into the air, transforming into a golden body eighteen feet tall. Xi, astonished and reverent, prostrated himself and kowtowed, saying, “The Dao Lord is supremely sagely and divine, his transformations unfathomable. Your servant’s blood and saliva are foul and impure; to be graced with an audience of your celestial presence fills me with awe and joy. I humbly entreat your instruction.”

The Old Lord said, “Attend carefully to my command: I bestow upon you the *Daodejing*. Master it, and you shall ascend to heaven, becoming a master of immortals.”

Xi replied, “Though your servant has long purified his heart, I have been mired in the floating world. Yet by karmic fortune, I have received this sacred grace.” He bowed twice, kowtowed, and received the scripture, then said, “I reverently embrace this profound decree, seeking only to cultivate and perfect it to the end of my days, never daring to neglect or lose it. By upholding this covenant, reciting in purity, I shall retire from office and attain perfection.”

Later, he visited the Old Lord, who appointed Xi as the Celestial Lord of the Twenty-Eight Heavens, the Supreme Perfected One. Initially, the Old Lord had revealed his golden body to Xi, but afterward, he resumed his true form of the Nine Heavens. Taking leave of Xi, he journeyed west to the eighty-one lands beyond the Flowing Sands. Arriving in India, he propagated the arts of the floating pagoda to transform the Hu people, and in that land, all called him the Venerable Master of Antiquity.

In the forty-fourth year (*renshen*, 953 BCE), on the eighth day of the second month, Śākyamuni received the Dao from him in Yucheng. With each sentence of the scripture he received, his body merged with the Great Ultimate, and the Supreme Emperor paid homage from afar. After reciting it ten thousand times, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Truly, when reciting scriptures, one must seek a place of purity and stillness, unifying heart and spirit, meditating upon the Primal Sage. Thus, the ninefold ancestors and sevenfold forebears shall all be reborn in heaven. The text is secretly preserved in the Golden Towers of the Three Clarities and the immortal caves of various mountains, inscribed on golden tablets and jade slips, attended by immortal youths and maidens who burn incense in vigil. When the great kalpa turns and the world nears its end, the Lords of the Grotto-Heavens shall gather the texts and return them to the Golden Towers of the Grand Clarity.

In the fifth year of King Mu’s reign (*jiashen*, 972 BCE), the Old Lord returned to the Central Kingdom and transmitted to the king the arts of immortal travel and aerial chariotry. In the twenty-eighth year of King Xuan’s reign (*xinchou*, 801 BCE), the Three Rivers trembled. The king asked the Old Lord, “What is this portent?”

The Old Lord replied, “I have heard a song in the suburbs: ‘When Venus enters Xuanyuan, the state’s ruler shall decline.’ In the reign of King You, Mount Qi collapsed. The Old Lord said, ‘In ancient times, when the Yi and Luo rivers dried, the Xia perished; when the Yellow River dried, the Shang perished. Now, Mount Qi has collapsed and the rivers have run dry—this state shall perish.’” The Old Lord bestowed upon the king the *Hidden Writ of the Three Heavens*, but the king did not revere the celestial texts. The Old Lord retrieved the writ and departed, and the king was later slain by the Quan Rong.

In the third year of King Huan’s reign (*jiazi*, 717 BCE), the Old Lord rode a white deer, accompanied by twenty-four immortals, with Guiguzi as his charioteer. He ascended Kunlun in the west and passed through Hangu Pass again. The Celestial Lord of the Twenty-Eight Heavens, the Supreme Perfected One, learned of the Old Lord’s return and descended from heaven to pay homage, following his carriage to the Palace of the Queen Mother before taking leave. The Old Lord then appointed Xi as the Celestial Lord of the Thirty-Two Heavens.

In the seventeenth year of King Xiang’s reign (*yiyou*, 635 BCE), the Old Lord returned to the Central Kingdom. The king’s scribe, whose name was later changed to Danran, revered him. Confucius traveled to Zhou and inquired of the rites from the Old Lord. The Old Lord said, “The man of whom you speak—his bones have long since decayed; only his words remain. I have heard that a good merchant conceals his wealth as if empty, and a gentleman of great virtue appears foolish. Rid yourself of your pride, anger, and excessive desires, for these bring no benefit to your person. This is why I tell you thus.”

Confucius departed and said to his disciples, “Birds—I know they can fly, and so I make snares. Beasts—I know they can run, and so I make nets. Fish—I know they can swim, and so I make lines. But as for the dragon, I cannot know how it rides the wind and clouds to ascend heaven. Today, I have seen Laozi—is he not like the dragon? I am but a mayfly in comparison.”

Confucius returned to Lu and declared Laozi a sage of all directions, one who is trusted without speaking, who transforms without governing—truly, he may be called a sage. One hundred and nineteen years after Confucius’ death, the Old Lord appeared to Duke Xian of Qin, saying, “At first, Qin and Zhou were united; after five hundred years, they separated. Ten years after their separation, a hegemon-king shall arise.” At that time, he was called the Grand Historian of Zhou.

The Old Lord was born in the time of King Wuding of Shang. Sometimes he appeared, sometimes he concealed himself, dwelling in the world for nine hundred years before ascending Mount Zizhu in the Purple Tenuity. The mountain lies within the borders of Quren County, and thus it is called the Ascension Mound of Laozi.

The Mystic Master says: I have perused all the records of the Dao, seeking their essential meaning. Yet many who delight in immortality have fabricated and compiled recklessly. When examining their historical accounts, the dates often conflict, and when tracing their wondrous traces, the beginnings and ends are scattered and incoherent, their words empty and extravagant, losing all truth. Such matters are not trivial, and I have omitted them entirely. I have instead consulted external sources and verified them against the jade tablets, recording only what is indelible through the ages. I title this the *Inner Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Old Lord*, leaving a true record to correct the floating words.

Here ends the *Inner Preface to the Golden Writ of the Most High Old Lord*.

gy, had retired to serve as the Pass Prefect. He built a thatched tower to observe the stars and await auspicious omens. Suddenly, he saw a purple qi rising in the east, serpentine as a dragon, moving westward. He urgently instructed the pass officers, “A sage is about to pass. If you see an ancient-looking figure traveling discreetly in a carriage drawn by a black ox, do not let him slip by.”

The officers replied, “Understood.” They then swept the roads and burned incense to await his arrival.
